Problem:
Consider a function \( z(w) \) mapping complex numbers where \( z(w) \) is defined as \( z(w) = e^{i\omega w} \), with \( \omega \) being a real constant. We explore the implications of an integral transformation \( Z(v) \) on \( z(w) \), defined by \( Z(v) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} z(w) e^{-ivw} dw \).

If an additional phase shift transformation \( G(w) = z(w)e^{ia} \) (with \( a \) being a real constant) is applied before \( Z(v) \), will \( Z(v) \) still isolate the Fourier component at \( v \) without modification?
Explanation: The intervention \( G(w) = z(w)e^{ia} \) adds a constant phase shift \( a \) to each frequency component of \( z(w) \). While \( Z(v) \) will still isolate the component at frequency \( v \), it will do so with an altered phase, thus influencing the outcome by shifting the phase of the transformed function.
